Structural Induction

Jordan Bell
(January 2023)

Let E be the smallest set such that

  • •

    x,y,z∈E

  • •

    if e1,e2∈E, then (e1+e2)∈E

For e∈E, define

  • •

    B⁢(e) to be the number of binary operators in e

  • •

    P⁢(e) to be the number of parentheses in e

Since the only binary operator that occurs, B⁢(e) is the number of occurrences of ’+’ in e.

Define Q⁢(e): P⁢(e)=2⋅B⁢(e).

Base cases

P⁢(x)=0 and B⁢(x)=0, so Q⁢(x) is true.

P⁢(y)=0 and B⁢(y)=0, so Q⁢(y) is true

P⁢(z)=0 and B⁢(z)=0, so Q⁢(z) is true

Inductive step

Suppose e1,e2∈E and Q⁢(e1) and Q⁢(e2) are true. By the recursive rule, e=(e1+e2)∈E. We wish to prove that Q⁢(e) is true.

P⁢(e) =P⁢((e1+e2))
=2+P⁢(e1)+P⁢(e2)
=2+2⋅B⁢(e1)+2⋅B⁢(e2)
B⁢(e) =B⁢((e1+e2))
=1+B⁢(e1)+B⁢(e2)

Thus

P⁢(e)=2⋅B⁢(e),

showing that Q⁢(e) is true.

Conclusion By structural induction, the predicate Q⁢(e) is true for all e∈E.
